## Week 1: January 9
### Toward critical practice: Transcending the quantitative/qualitative divide
#### Read:
- Kenneth R. Howe, 1992, [Getting Over the Quantitative-Qualitative Debate](https://www.jstor.org/stable/1085569#metadata_info_tab_contents), *American Journal of Education* 100: 236-256.
- Todd Presner, 2015, [Critical Theory and the Mangle of Digital Humanities](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/ebooks/bookPdfWithBanner.jsp?fileName=7121169.pdf&bkn=7120877&pdfType=chapter), pp. 55-67 in Patrik Svensson and David Theo Goldberg, eds., *Between Humanities and the Digital* (Cambridge: MIT Press).
- Barbara Herrnstein Smith, 2016, [What was "Close Reading"? A Century of Method in Literary Studies](https://doi.org/10.1215/00265667-3630844), *The Minnesota Review* 87: 57-75.
- Ted Underwood, 2017, [A Genealogy of Distant Reading](http://www.digitalhumanities.org/dhq/vol/11/2/000317/000317.html), *Digital Humanities Quarterly* 11(2).

### Notebook: Introduction to text manipulation in R
- Install [R](https://r-project.org) and [RStudio](https://www.rstudio.com) on your machine. You may find [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EmZqlcKkJMM) helpful.
- If you do not have previous experience with R, I recommend that you work through the following [videos](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeOVpKuuxX5sdOmGd7P9zzw/videos). These will walk you through sections 2.2 - 2.6 of [Humanities Data in R](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007%2F978-3-319-20702-5), showing you how to work with R in the command line ([Part 1](https://youtu.be/e2fKTpqsi48)), RStudio console ([Part 2a](https://youtu.be/eMdD9FW1tos)), R scripts (Parts [2b](https://youtu.be/E149gT17nGk) and [3](https://youtu.be/5jrCpa2lRmo)), and R Markdown notebooks (Parts [4a](https://youtu.be/6fFO3za5mHQ), [4b](https://youtu.be/lI7v7iWgcwk), and [4c](https://youtu.be/Ej3wVsp1OqM)).
